Larru, first of all, I really enjoy reading your posts. Thank you for taking the time to do so. Please keep posting when you can. 

Regarding put options, what would you like to know?  GCT options are traded monthly, and the expiration of options is every third Friday of the month. If you buy a put at a certain strike price, you have the right to sell the stock at the strike price to who sold you the put. However, if you sell a put, the one who bought it has the right to sell the stock to you at the strike price. Generally, such actions are taken on the day of option expiration, and it can be done up to either 5:00 or 6:00 PM on the day of expiration (note, this is 1 or 2 hours after the market closes). 

People buy puts for two reasons.  First, if they believe the stock will go down and if so, they will make money. They don’t have to put up too much money for it. Therefore, the percent return can be significantly higher than from stock sale/purchase. They can close the position whenever they wish. Second, as a hedge for the stocks they own. People also can sell a put, if they wish to buy a stock only at a certain price below the actual stock price. If the stock goes below the strike price, they will end up buying the stock at the strike price. If the stock remains above the strike price, they will pocket the premium they received when they sold the put.

There's an article on Seeking Alpha and GCT called GigaCloud Technologies – Refuting Grizzly Short Seller Claims by Lawrence Fuller. It's a deep dive into accounting regulations and website traffic and related companies and it's the best article I've read on this company. Before reading the article I had already independently confirmed the website traffic of GCT and that Griz misrepresented the numbers in their short report or were for some reason confused by the data and had reached an erroneous conclusion. Beyond that, Fuller writes about FASB 606 which concerns how the company recognizes revenue and that since it is a "principal" as defined by 606 it needs to include shipping costs in Gross revenues, and they also deduct that in the COGS. Bottomline is such a practice is not fraud, it's required so again the folks at Griz seem to lack FASB knowledge since their report reached the wrong conclusion. The related parties are a little more difficult to get absolute evidence but Fuller notes that the companies that Griz claims are omitted from related parties are legacy companies dating back to when the company was in retail, but the company is not in that business now and so their existence is not relevant to GCT. Fuller notes other issues, insider sales and the company's transition process to a US audit firm is a WIP at this time for reasons noted by Fuller. Fuller notes his target is $50 which is lower than mine. You should read Fuller's article whether your short or long!

Some more research: The headwinds are very significant. Every company in the BtoC furniture market saw a decline in revenue YOY but an increase from Q1 to Q2. All of them, including big companies like wayfair and amazon, pointed to the fact that the housing market is frozen, with minimal buying due to high prices and high interest rates. Wayfair believes we are approaching the bottom of this cycle, but they are not sure when the rebound will occur. Guidance for these companies was also in line with historical performance, meaning they expect Q3 to be down vs Q2 due to a slowdown in consumer spending associated with the summer months. Opinion: The bad furniture market is not new. It has been this way for the past 2 years and GCT has been able to grow despite it. That said I would be blown away if we exceed guidance this quarter the way we have in the past. I would be really happy with anything north of 265m and getting to 275m would be a gift.

Traditionally, most retailers commit on seasonal purchasing 8-12 months before the season occurs, this includes candy for Halloween, Christmas, Easter, etc. perishable is done about 6 months out to give growers and farmers an idea of what to produce. So as it pertains to furniture, I would imagine that orders were booked 8-12 months ago, and retailers are sitting on the product. The easy tell would be if GCT’s WSOH (Weeks Supply On Hand) increased from the 4.5 weeks from the last conference call which would indicate that GCT has excess inventory.

Here is some research: Bad: I went through just about every public furniture seller I could find that has reported(Ethan Alen, MillerKnoll, Bassett Furniture, Mohawk Industries, Beyond, wayfair) and all showed declining revenues YOY in Q2. The exception was NHI.  Good: Amazon just reported they were losing market share "On the ecommerce front to the likes of Temu and Shein, companies that specialize in low-cost goods that rely on a direct-from-factory supply chain." This is exactly the business GCT is in. Amazon went on to say: “We are seeing cautious consumers. They are looking for deals.” It is worth pointing out that Temu and Shein are not in the furniture market they are in fashion, neither is public, and both are chinese companies. I have no way of knowing which of these two pieces of info is more powerful the good or the bad, so I wanted to share both.
